  • Deprecated Interfaces 
    Interface and Description
    org.swerverobotics.library.internal.II2cDevice
    Code that previously used II2cDevice should use I2cDevice instead.
    org.swerverobotics.library.interfaces.II2cDeviceClient
    Code that previously used II2cDeviceClient should use I2cDeviceSynch instead.
    org.swerverobotics.library.interfaces.II2cDeviceClientUser
    Code that previously used II2cDeviceClientUser should use I2cDeviceSynchUser instead.
  • Deprecated Classes 
    Class and Description
    org.swerverobotics.library.internal.I2cDeviceOnI2cDeviceController
    Code that previously used I2cDeviceOnI2cDeviceController should use I2cDeviceImpl instead
  • Deprecated Fields 
    Field and Description
    org.swerverobotics.library.SynchronousOpMode.NANO_TO_MILLI
    use ElapsedTime.MILLIS_IN_NANO instead.
    org.swerverobotics.library.SynchronousOpMode.unthunkedHardwareMap
    This member variable is redundant; use SynchronousOpMode.getUnprocessedHardwareMap() instead.
  • Deprecated Methods 
    Method and Description
    org.swerverobotics.library.ClassFactory.createEasyLegacyMotorController(OpMode, DcMotor, DcMotor)
    Deprecated because of a poor choice of API name: insufficiently general.
    org.swerverobotics.library.ClassFactory.createEasyMotorController(OpMode, DcMotor, DcMotor)
    This functionality is now included in the core SDK; the implementation of this method is now effectively a nop. If the provided motors are using a legacy motor controller, createEasyMotorController swaps that controller out and installs an alternate 'EasyLegacyMotorController' DCMotorController implementation for the duration of the OpMode. If the motors are using a modern motor controller, an analogous swap to an 'EasyModernMotorController' is made. If a matrix motor controller is in use, this function has no effect. The APIs to easy legacy and modern motor controllers are identical, which helps simplify programming.

    EasyLegacyMotorController is implemented on top of an I2cDeviceSynch instance which completely handles all the complexities of read vs write mode switching and the like, allowing the logic inside the controller itself to be extraordinarily simple. In particular, the manual mode switching and loop() counting necessary with the stock controller implementation is not needed. Just call the motor getPosition() or setPower() methods or what have you, and the necessary bookkeeping details will be taken care of.

    The improvements in EasyModernMotorController are less dramatic, but still significant. Of particular note is that write operations, including motor mode and power changes, happen immediately rather than being deferred to the end of a loop() cycle. This significantly simplifies the steps that are necessary to create code that uses a modern motor controller reliably.

    Easy motor controllers are not tied to SynchronousOpMode or any other particular OpMode. They can be used, for example, from LinearOpModes. In SynchronousOpMode, easy motor controllers are used automatically; in other OpModes, you'll have to manually call ClassFactory.createEasyMotorController(com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode, com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotor, com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotor) yourself.

    This method takes as parameters one or both motors that reside on a given motor controller. If two motors are provided, they must share the same controller, and conversely if two motors reside on a controller then both must be provided. The method creates a new easy motor controller of the appropriate type and installs it as the controller for the provided motors; the existing controller is disabled. When the current OpMode is complete, the processed is reversed.
    org.swerverobotics.library.ClassFactory.createEasyServoController(OpMode, Collection)
    This functionality is now included in the core SDK; the implementation of this method is now effectively a nop. Creates an alternate 'easy' implementation of the controller for the indicated collection of servos, which must all share the same controller, and must be all the servos which are found on that controller. A notable feature of the easy servo controller implementation is that position change requests and other servo writes are issued immediately instead of being deferred to the end of the next loop() cycle, which simplifies programming. This is similar to the enhancements found in the easy motor controller. Some small bugs are also fixed.
    org.swerverobotics.library.ClassFactory.createI2cDevice(I2cDevice)
    I2cDevice, as defined in the SDK, is now an interface, not an implementation, so this API is no longer necessary.
    org.swerverobotics.library.ClassFactory.createI2cDeviceClient(OpMode, I2cDevice, int, boolean)
    The creation API has been renamed to match changes in interface nomenclature. Use createI2cDeviceSynch() instead.
    org.swerverobotics.library.SynchronousOpMode.waitForThreadsWritesToReachHardware()
    Thunking support is being removed
    org.swerverobotics.library.SynchronousOpMode.waitOneFullHardwareCycle()
  • Deprecated Constructors 
    Constructor and Description
    org.swerverobotics.library.TelemetryDashboardAndLog(Telemetry)
    This constructor is no longer necessary. Use TelemetryDashboardAndLog.TelemetryDashboardAndLog() instead.
